author: Morgan Housel
summary: Do not aim to be coldly rational with money - aim to be reasonable. Reasonable is more realistic and you have a better chance of sticking with it for the long run. What works on a spreadsheet might be emotionally impossible to sustain.
key_takeaways: Being reasonable is more sustainable than being perfectly rational.
The strategy that maximizes how well you sleep at night often beats the mathematically optimal one.
Loving your investments helps you stick with them through hard times.

questions.question: Why is being 'reasonable' often better than being 'rational' with money?

options.text: Reasonable is more realistic and you're more likely to stick with it long-term

questions.explanation: Do not aim to be coldly rational when making financial decisions. Aim to just be pretty reasonable. Reasonable is more realistic and you have a better chance of sticking with it for the long run.

questions.question: Why did Nobel Prize winner Harry Markowitz split his portfolio 50/50 between stocks and bonds instead of using his own optimal formulas?

options.text: He wanted to minimize future regret, not maximize mathematical returns

questions.explanation: Markowitz said he visualized his grief if the market went up and he wasn't in it, or if it went down and he was completely in it. His intention was to minimize future regret, not optimize mathematically.

questions.question: Why is it actually rational to 'love your investments' even though this seems emotionally driven?

options.text: Emotional investors always outperform logical ones
If you love your investments, you're more likely to stick with them through difficult times
Love creates positive energy that affects stock prices

questions.explanation: There are few financial variables more correlated to performance than commitment to a strategy during its lean years. If you love your investments, the inevitable down times are blunted by feeling part of something meaningful.
